Content:
I still think there is a big disconnect here on what an oracle actually is. Ironically enough Zack claiming Komodo is lying (about something?) means we all should have been in agreement to what Zack's definition of Oracle is, making him the "Oracle" of it's definition. Which doesn't seem to be the case. As defined by Komodo's actual documents
<https://github.com/KomodoPlatform/Mastering_CryptoConditions/blob/master/all_chapters.md#chapter-11---oracles-example>
<https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/cryptoconditions/cc-oracles.html#introduction> 

The definition is simply ```"Just what is an oracle? In this context it is something that puts data that is not on the blockchain, onto the blockchain."```
Zack I believe said that an Oracle MUST be trustless?

Author: zack#6467
Content:
If I made a blockchain to compete with ethereum, and it has smart contracts, but all the smart contracts were trustful, and I didn't warn any of the users that the contracts were all trustful, I would consider that a scam. Wouldn't you also consider that a scam?

Because with blockchain projects, everything is supposed to be trustless, and you need to warn people when you use trust.
It isn't logical to have trust on-chain, because a blockchain is expensive and the only benefit it gives is trustlessness.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: ```The most difficult issue about oracles is that they need to be trusted to various degree to provide accurate and timely data. The danger is that if a trusted node is used to write data to the blockchain, it creates a trust point and a single point of attack. Ultimately there is nothing that can ensure only valid data is written to the blockchain, so what is done is to reinforce good behavior via pay per datapoint. However, for critical data, higher level processing is needed that combines multiple data providers into a validated signal.```

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: You do realize game theory isn't trustless right? Nor is game theory a mathematical certainty. It's a way to measure/layout incentives of rational participants who's incentive is in the outcome of the game itself. Game theory doesn't account for those participants whose incentive is derived outside said game, or in the failure of the game itself, or are simply irrational actors.

Author: zack#6467
Content: Sounds like Vitalik likes to use different jargon from me. I haven't talked to him in like 3 years, so it isn't so surprising that we talk differently.

Author: MyName#0491
Content:
`You do realize game theory isn't trustless right?`
That being the 10th or 12th time he's written "Nash equilibrium", I'm confident in saying "No, he doesn't"

Author: zack#6467
Content:
game theory is sort of the reverse of mechanism design.
With game theory you are trying to find the best strategy for an existing game.
With mechanism design you are trying to create a game such that the best strategy is your goal.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
I don't know what it means to say "game theory is trustless".
Game theory is math, which is a collection of algorithms. 
"trustless" is a word you  use to describe if a protocol has certain properties.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Game theory is measuring incentives for rational players, most often measured with some basic math. That means nothing in context of what you said earlier ```Cryptoeconomics combines game theory and cryptographic protocols so that you can have mathematical guarantees about the reliability of your protocol. This is what is meant by "trustless" or "secure".```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```
In computer programming, a pure function is a function that has the following properties:[1][2]

Its return value is the same for the same arguments (no variation with local static variables, non-local variables, mutable reference arguments or input streams from I/O devices).
Its evaluation has no side effects (no mutation of local static variables, non-local variables, mutable reference arguments or I/O streams).
```
